results.title: Princess of the Blood Robes from The Last Emperor
results.brief_description:
A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.

results.title: Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission [event version]
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission’ was the second in the series of Cyberthon broadcast events. Set up from TVU’s (Television Unlimited) warehouse and studio in Footscray Victoria, it was once again broadcast live via RMITV’s frequency UHF-31. Unlike the previous Cyberthon and Cyberdelia broadcast events however, Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission had expanded in scope afforded by its new venue and increasing popularity of the techno scene.

Adding to the DJ, VJ sets, live performances of electronic music and art, a range of artists also performed live. Artists such as Stelarc performed his Third Arm and Craig Horsham displayed his subversive VHS crash editing of mainstream TV commercials. The Amiga Users Group exhibited a collection of Amiga demos while a diverse range of artists displayed accompanying complex visual effects and art installations.

This is the event version of ‘Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission’. For the [1-hour compilation] see title B2004202

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi), Bureau of Inverse Technology - BIT (Natalie Jeremijenko, Kate Rich and Danny Tigani), Amiga Users Group, Craig Horsham, Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson)

Audio Artists: Third Eye ‘Ambi Jam’ (Gus Till, Ollie Olsen, Geoffrey Hales, Simon Polinski), Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac), Foil (Neil Boyack, Andrew Coates, Steve Law, Chris Grierson), 1x4x9 (Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Tribal (Duncan Gray, Bruce Yardley & Cam Saunderson), Extroversion (Kate Armstrong), Hardware (Richie ‘Rich’ McNeil), Mystic Force (Russell Hancorne), Poets of the Machine (Koral Island & Stripe)

Performers: Stelarc, Just to fresh, Computer Graphture (Simone Millman and Tanya Hoddinott), Space Between The Gaps (Paul Gafney), Jacinta Le Plastrier, Yoga (Mary Galick, Bronwyn Richie & Paul Gafney), Zenep Jaffers

Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon I: For the Mind, Body and Soul
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ was the first guerrilla TV broadcast event of its namesake following the success of the Cyberdelia broadcast a year earlier. Conceptualised as a ‘marathon cyber’ event, ‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ saw a group of artists broadcast, remix, VJ and DJ mastered footage, experimental Amiga graphics and electronic art alongside performers and a live band at RMITV’s studio in Melbourne. Collaborator and curator to the events, Adem Jaffers said this is where the Cyberthon events really began and over the next four years they would expand in scope to feature over 300 VJ’s, DJ’s, artists, performers and collaborators. 

Visual Artists: Nuero (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent, Dale Nason and Elena Popa), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Interscreen (Kimberley Hughes), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi)

Audio Artists: Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac and Terence ‘H20’ Ho), Third Eye (Ollie Olsen), Acid Death Bed (Darren Porter and Paul Wain), Baby Lemonade Lemar (Andrea), Captain ROM

Performers: Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki

‘Cyberthon I: For the Mind Body and Soul’ is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: DIGGERMODE
results.brief_description:
“Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction and storage, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind-the-servers look into how memory works within platform capitalism.”

“DIGGERMODE” questions the social and environmental ethics of technology in constructing, storing and sharing our images, whether in surveillance databases, museum archives or online. With artificial intelligence (AI), Joel Sherwood Spring has created landscapes in the style of acclaimed Arrernte artist Albert Namatjira being torn apart by mining machinery, and has trained another AI to answer questions like “Who’s your Mob?” Presumably, anyone could do this – but should anyone be able to appropriate Indigenous art from the internet? How do we protect our knowledges in digital spaces? Can sand used to make silicon microchips contain memories of Country?

Joel’s work confronts the viewer with uncomfortable and overlooked aspects of our hyper-networked age, grounding the possibilities of ‘the cloud’ and AI in the broader context of ongoing colonisation. The work considers the environmental damage caused by new technology and data storage, and how it is Indigenous peoples whose lands and ways of being are profoundly impacted by capitalism’s extractive processes.

constellations_primary.name: Extraction
constellations_primary.description: Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind the scenes investigates how memory works within platform capitalism.

constellations_other.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
constellations_other.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

Videographer: Akil Ahamat

Sound production: Bridget Chappelle

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: How I See It: Blak Art and Film → Zone 6

results.title: Saltburn trend
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

At the end of Saltburn, Oliver Quick (Barry Keogahn) dances triumphantly through a mansion to Sophie Ellis Baxter’s “Murder on the Dancefloor”. Emmerald Fennel’s caustic comment on class is one of the most divisive films of 2023, but despite its mixed reception has inspired a popular TikTok trend, which sees the hit song remixed over footage of people dancing through mansions. This video is a typical example, with the user effectively assembling a snapshot of privilege via their smartphone and editing software. However, as the comments attest, the trend has come under fire for missing the supposedly satirical point of the film.
description_for_label: At the end of Saltburn, Oliver Quick (Barry Keogahn) dances triumphantly through a mansion to Sophie Ellis Baxter’s “Murder on the Dancefloor”. Despite Emmerald Fennel’s caustic comment on class being one of the most divisive films of 2023, it’s inspired a popular TikTok trend, which sees the hit song remixed over footage of people dancing through mansions. However, as the comments attest, the trend has come under fire for missing the supposedly satirical point of the film.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family visit to the beach and backyard play in Point Lonsdale c1950s -1960s. We see the children (James, Andrew and Margaret) with their mother and father playing on the seashore, building sandcastles together and drawing pictures in the sand. Joined by their pet dog, the children fill their buckets with sand and play with seaweed washed up onto the beach. There are good closeups of the children, reflecting examples of children’s fashion and hairstyles of the era.

We see the children venture out to the edge of the water and then play along the top of the seawall. There is great delight while eating ice cream from cones, and tears shed when an adult takes an uninvited taste.

The second, third and fourth sections of the film show the children on a summer’s day in a backyard. Tricycles, a blow-up wading pool with the backyard hose leading into it, swings and a sand pit create a great snapshot of children’s recreation, toys, and equipment particular to the era. We also see a young boy kicking what appears to be an American shaped football and two boys playing with toy cars and a toy police car.

The fifth section of the film shows a young baby being held by her mother. We then see the baby lying in her pram and being closely inspected and entertained by her older sibling.

We then go back to the beach with three very young children playing on the water’s edge with their mother beside them. Adults sit on the sand socialising, and there are scenes on the veranda of a holiday house. We see great examples of beach fashion, women’s hats, and children’s swimsuits.

This film shows examples of Victoria in the summertime, beach, women’s fashion and children’s fashion, children’s swim wear, vintage toys and a perambulator, children’s leisure and recreation activities that reflect the time.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:18:00 Mother and three boys playing in the sand
00:02:25:00 Children filling buckets with sand
00:02:36:00 Two children filling buckets with sand
00:03:09:00 Young boy crawling along the sea wall
00:03:34:00 Eating ice creams from cones, offering to share with passers by
00:03:50:00 Close up of eating ice cream
00:06:25:00 Three children on their tricycles with backyard swing
00:06:56:00 Two boys swing on their backyard bench swing
00:07:03 :00 Three children on swing
00:07:24:00 Children playing in sandpit
00:08:36:00 Nice wide shot of children playing on swing and in the sandpit
00:09:52:00 Three children playing in blow up wading pool
00:10:17:00 Three children crowded on a backyard swing together
00:10:32:00 Children trying to move wading pool full of water across the grass
00:12:44:00 Boys play with toy police car in sand pit
00:14:08:00 Children play with what appears to be an American shaped football
00:15:32:00 Boy riding on vintage tricycle in front of house
00:17:13:00 Baby in vintage pram with sibling peering in and attempting to play
00:17:53:00 Mother and three very young children sit at the water’s edge
00:18:15:00 Very young child at water’s edge – good example of children’s swim wear
00:20:28:00 Family on veranda of holiday house with seascape in background
00:21:48:00 Three women sitting on the beach wearing great hats
00:22:51:00 Great family beach scene as above

We then go back to the beach with three very young children playing on the water’s edge with their mother beside them. Adults sit on the sand socialising, and there are scenes on the veranda of a holiday house. We see great examples of beach fashion, women’s hats, and children’s swimsuits.

This film shows examples of Victoria in the summertime, beach, women’s fashion and children’s fashion, children’s swim wear, vintage toys and a perambulator, children’s leisure and recreation activities that reflect the time.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:

00:02:25:00 Children filling buckets with sand
00:02:36:00 Two children filling buckets with sand
00:03:09:00 Young boy crawling along the sea wall

00:03:50:00 Close up of eating ice cream
00:06:25:00 Three children on their tricycles with backyard swing
00:06:56:00 Two boys swing on their backyard bench swing
00:07:03 :00 Three children on swing
00:07:24:00 Children playing in sandpit
00:08:36:00 Nice wide shot of children playing on swing and in the sandpit
00:09:52:00 Three children playing in blow up wading pool
00:10:17:00 Three children crowded on a backyard swing together
00:10:32:00 Children trying to move wading pool full of water across the grass
00:12:44:00 Boys play with toy police car in sand pit
00:14:08:00 Children play with what appears to be an American shaped football
00:15:32:00 Boy riding on vintage tricycle in front of house
00:17:13:00 Baby in vintage pram with sibling peering in and attempting to play
00:17:53:00 Mother and three very young children sit at the water’s edge

results.title: Cyberthon VI: VAT
results.brief_description:
After the success of Spectrum, the Cyberthon artists were invited by Telstra to create a submission for an exhibition called The Edge, to be displayed at the Telstra Corporate Center on Exhibition Street. This demo was presented to Telstra at an annual meeting held at Dallas Brooks Hall.

The demo shows a CGI artists impression of the proposed ‘The Edge exhibition’ space as well as a simulation of the media submission process via the interactive Cyberthon VAT (V=Video, A=Audio, T=Text) porthole created using Deluxe Paint, with presentation edited in Scala on an Amiga 2000.

Animation loops that appear in simulated submission section were created by Ian Haig, Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent and Dale Nason), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton & Attillio Gangemi), Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Julian Wong, Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Derek Shiel, Martine Corompt, and Force Fed (Stuart McCormick). Video camera footage was shot by Dale Nason from the back of a Chris Wrights moving van. 35mm still photographs were taken by Tao Wiess. Audio track was mixed by DJ Visitor (Andrew Till).

This work is part of the Cyberthon Archive, generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Titled The Stars Were. This film shows closeups of the children who starred in “Walking to School” and “The Bear”.

The film then moves on to show a tractor dragging flames to set fire to a dry paddock. We see various farm scenery including sheep, burning off, horse riding and a tractor ploughing a field.

The film then shows a narrative short story titled “The Wish Wizard” which could be an Eaglehawk Primary school production. This film shows school children discovering a book which contains a map to “The Olde Wishing Well”. They gather together and conjure up a wizard using a magic spell. We see good close ups of children’s faces as they interact with the wizard.

We then see a school boy walking and running down a country road where he discovers animal tracks in the dirt and encounters a woman wearing a red coat carrying apples in a basket.

This film shows good examples of school fashion, children’s faces and farming practices.

Selected highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:49:00 - Title card Story ‘The Bear’
00:01:05:00 - Burning off with tractor
00:02:56:00 - Title card ‘the wish wizard’

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a slice of life from a working dairy farm in central Gippsland, Victoria.

We see cows being milked, the milk cans being loaded onto trucks and in to the trays of utility cars. The milk is transported by road to the Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Company.

There are scenes of hay bales being driven around the paddocks in the back of a ute. The hay is divided in to sections and fed to the cattle. We see de-horned Jersey and Friesian cows and bulls eating the hay and children riding a WX 572 tractor.

There is footage of a newly born calf being licked clean by its mother and we see the calf’s first attempt to stand and take its first steps.

The film also shows a family visit to the Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point.

Selected sequence list (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:54:00 The Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Co LTD sign
00:02:12:00 Title card ‘A Calf is Born’
00:03:55:00 Dad and kids riding a tractor
00:04:00:00 Title card ‘Wattle Time’
00:04:38:00 Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point

results.title: Rodeo Baby!
results.brief_description:
“The artwork is centred upon the belief that it is our own bodies that are the truest archive of our experience and that any documentation is only ever an approximation of the person doing the gazing – not the gazed.”

While trawling archival video material, Jazz Money discovered an overwhelming amount of footage of First Peoples in rodeos. There was the joy of seeing Blak faces, but an unease in knowing non-Indigenous voyeurs likely captured the footage. In the vast network of archives in this country’s institutions, photos and videos of First Peoples are filed away, with the people who have been recorded – often unknowingly – and their descendants unaware the recordings exist.

Jazz reclaims these images, combining them with stills from film and TV, including “The Phantom Stockman” (1953), “Radiance” (1998) and” The Drover’s Wife” (2021), in this large-scale photographic essay. It celebrates First Peoples representation and the Aboriginal scholars who critique this colonial hoarding, giving new meaning to images that have been dislocated by archival practices. Jazz asks, “If these archival collections are the rodeo, who is playing cowboy with our images?”

constellations_primary.name: Reclaiming the archive
constellations_primary.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

constellations_other.name: Extraction
constellations_other.description: Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind the scenes investigates how memory works within platform capitalism.
